text: [Music]
our choice to go with AWS we've driven
both by technical characteristics but
also what we knew was coming around the
corner in terms of our ability to
innovate and make our products better
there are certain products and there are
certain features that we wouldn't be
able to offer unless we gain the scaling
capabilities from AWS alert logic to
secure cloud environments cloud
workloads a lot of our work involves
helping customers through their cloud
migration helping them take their
applications out of traditional data
centers move them into AWS as an
environment our customers trust us to
store their data in some cases for up to
seven seven to ten years these are
compliance requirements that means that
the archive has to move to to a place
where we can easily access it so we have
data for our customers in some cases
staged in multiple locations in US and
in UK our job is to make sure that they
not only gain that level of trust but
also that they realized that in fact by
moving to the applied environment they
can be even more secure than they were
on premises today we've have about 25
petabytes of customer data under
management before five years ago that
wasn't as much we were just you know
topping about a petabyte of data so you
only get so much performance out of that
footprint and what we would struggle
with was to be able to find economic
solutions that had a sufficient amount
of performance that fits into that
footprint of storage and that was a good
decision for three years we have 4,000
customers we tagged the data by customer
and by the sort of month in which it
occurs we use those tags to turn on per
customer analytics and then we use that
to be able to publish to sort of the
rest of the business what each customer
is both consuming from you know just a
consumption of data on disk that we
haven't expired - you know what their
actual usage pattern is one of the up
shots of us making the migration of this
data from our physical data centers into
AWS and s3 and it ends up being less
than half of the cost of our current
footprint that is fully redundant that's
fully multi-region that's
you know recallable within a few minutes
it's just not something that we have
access to in the physical data centers
during that migration we had the
opportunity to test the scale of it so
that we tested a hundred times our
current production load all of the
metrics reflect our 95th latency on
rites of s3 were at 200 milliseconds and
at the 31,000 rites per second they were
still 200 milliseconds and I think the
most unique part of our migration is
that it wasn't an executive mandate
given to our development team it was
very much an organic process we started
to build it with AWS components in mind
and gaining new scaling characteristics
which were weren't able to do before
we got involved with s3 team and talked
about tagging beta by March of this year
myself and one other engineer had built
this solution and we had migrated and
demonstrated the hundred times our
production scale on that system in
production so it was a pivotal change
for us
we have almost no one dedicated to doing
infrastructure operations anymore the
development teams now own their services
their components their subsystems these
changes are seamless to customers they I
don't think our customers realize
exactly where their data resides they
know that we as a service provider or
responsible for resiliency and
performance and security of their data
but exactly how its managed I think is
seamless to them so we've been able to
move major were closed AWS behind the
scenes not really impacting the user
experience in a negative way at all in
fact a lot of them noticed that the
performance as we move is actually
increasing
you
